title: 108_s2919
content: The text introduces a new subpart in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, providing a nonrefundable credit for holders of Indian Tribal Prison Facility Bonds. This credit is aimed at supporting Indian tribal prison facilities. The new subpart in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a nonrefundable credit for holders of Indian Tribal Prison Facility Bonds to support Indian tribal prison facilities. Taxpayers holding these bonds on credit allowance dates can claim a credit against their tax equal to the product of the credit rate determined by the Secretary and the face amount of the bond. The Secretary determines the credit rate monthly for bonds issued in the following month. The credit rate for Indian tribal prison facility bonds is determined monthly by the Secretary to allow issuance without discount or interest cost. The credit allowed for a taxable year is limited by the tax liability minus other credits. The credit amount is included in gross income as interest income. Indian tribal prison facility bonds must invest 95% or more of proceeds in investment grade obligations. The Indian tribal prison facility bonds must invest 95% or more of proceeds in investment grade obligations. The bonds are issued by the Indian tribe for the construction, acquisition, rehabilitation, or expansion of a qualified Indian tribal prison facility. The term of each bond cannot exceed 10 years, and no more than 2 percent of the sale proceeds can be used for issuance costs. A qualified Indian tribal prison facility is a residential correctional or detention facility located on the qualified Indian land of the issuing tribe. The Indian tribal prison facility bonds have a limitation of $200,000,000 for each year from 2005 to 2007, with zero allocation thereafter. The Secretary allocates the bonds among tribes with approved plans for investment proceeds usage. The Secretary allocates Indian tribal prison facility bonds based on approval criteria including prison overcrowding, facility conditions, health and safety, type of offenders, and financial resources available to the tribe. Unused limitation amounts can be carried over to the following year. The limitation amount for Indian tribal prison facility bonds can be carried forward to future years if it exceeds the amount issued in a calendar year. Definitions and special rules include the credit allowance date, bond obligations, Indian tribe definition, qualified Indian lands, and treatment of pass-thru entities like partnerships and S corporations. Entities like partnerships, trusts, S corporations, and other pass-thru entities are subject to rules similar to section 41(g) for the credit allowed under subsection (a). If Indian tribal prison facility bonds are held by regulated investment companies, the credit will be allowed to shareholders of such companies. Each Indian tribe with an allocation of these bonds must submit reports similar to those required under section 149(e). Conforming amendments include reporting requirements for the credit on Indian tribal prison facility bonds under subsection (a). The term 'interest' for purposes of subsection (a) includes amounts includible in gross income under section 54(d) and shall be treated as paid on the credit allowance date. Regulations may be prescribed for more detailed reporting. Section 6654 of the Code relates to failure by individuals to pay estimated taxes. The amendment adds a special rule for holders of Indian tribal prison facility bonds regarding the credit allowed for holding such bonds. The credit is treated as a payment of estimated tax made on the credit allowance date for both individuals and corporations. The credit is treated as a payment of estimated tax made on the credit allowance date for both individuals and corporations. Clerical amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendment adds a nonrefundable credit for holders of Indian tribal prison facility bonds to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 6401(b)(1) is amended to include this new credit. The effective date for these amendments is obligations issued after December 31, 2004.
